supporting.text: Muscle spasms and involuntary movements occur due to the body's reflexive response to asphyxiation and spinal cord trauma.

attacks.text: Muscle spasms and involuntary movements occur due to the body's reflexive response to asphyxiation and spinal cord trauma.
In some cases, death by hanging is instantaneous due to cervical spine fracture, leaving no time for reflexive movements.
Even with cervical spine fracture, residual nerve activity can still cause minor twitching or spasms post-trauma.
Modern forensic studies show that reflexive movements in hanging are often misinterpreted as signs of life by observers.
Misinterpretation does not negate the existence of the movements, only their diagnostic significance.

supporting.text: The force of the drop can cause the body to swing or rotate, especially if the rope is not perfectly still at the moment of suspension.

attacks.text: The force of the drop can cause the body to swing or rotate, especially if the rope is not perfectly still at the moment of suspension.
In controlled executions with minimal drop distance, the body may not swing significantly due to reduced momentum.
Even minimal drops can introduce slight movements due to uneven tension in the rope or anatomical asymmetries in the body.
If the rope is rigidly fixed and the drop is perfectly vertical, rotational movement is physically impossible.
Perfectly vertical drops are rare in practice due to environmental factors like wind or slight misalignment of the noose.

supporting.text: Convulsions may occur as the brain is deprived of oxygen, leading to uncontrolled limb movements.

attacks.text: Convulsions may occur as the brain is deprived of oxygen, leading to uncontrolled limb movements.
Convulsions are rare and not universally observed in all hangings, making this argument an exception rather than the norm.
Even if convulsions are rare, their occurrence is well-documented in medical literature, confirming that they do happen in some cases.
The movements during convulsions are not voluntary and thus do not constitute 'movement' in the conventional sense of the word.
The claim does not specify voluntary movement, and convulsions are still a form of bodily movement regardless of voluntariness.

supporting.text: The weight distribution and center of gravity of the body can shift during suspension, causing swaying or pendulum-like motion.

attacks.text: The weight distribution and center of gravity of the body can shift during suspension, causing swaying or pendulum-like motion.
If the body is fully rigid and suspended in a perfectly balanced position, there will be no movement due to weight distribution shifts.
Perfect rigidity and balance are practically impossible in real-world scenarios, making movement likely in most cases.
External forces such as wind or mechanical disturbances are usually required to initiate motion in a suspended body.
Internal factors like muscle relaxation or post-mortem changes can also cause shifts in weight distribution without external forces.
